channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Three Hospitals Attacked in Rebel Side of Aleppo, Syria
item.media:description: Syrians inspected damage on Wednesday after an airstrike in al-Shaar, a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo.
item.description: The hospitals were hit by airstrikes a day after President Bashar al-Assad vowed to take back “every inch” of territory held by his enemies.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Palestinian Gunmen Open Fire in Tel Aviv, Leaving Four Dead
item.media:description: People comforting one another after the attack.
item.description: One attacker is wounded and hospitalized, and the other is in custody, said the Israeli police.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Bangladesh Says It Now Knows Who’s Killing the Bloggers
item.media:description: Worshipers in March at the Hatembagh Jame Masjid in Dhaka, Bangladesh, where the spiritual leader of Ansar al-Islam used to lead prayers.
item.description: The police have implicated two militant groups in an accelerating series of attacks over the past three years and say they are preparing to round up their leaders.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: U.S. and India Mark a New Moment in Relations as Narendra Modi Speaks to Congress
item.media:description: Lawmakers jockeyed for Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s autograph on Wednesday after he spoke in the Capitol.
item.description: The prime minister, in an address to lawmakers in Washington, talked about the benefits of growing economic and military ties.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A French Minister, Who Inspires Applause and Anger, Considers a Bigger Stage
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, center, the French economy minister, with José Ángel Gurría, left, secretary general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, at a meeting this month in Paris.
item.description: Emmanuel Macron has started what many consider a campaign in all but name to explore whether to challenge François Hollande as the Socialist candidate for president.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Bracing for Terrorism: How France Is Preparing for Euro 2016
item.media:description: Police forces at a fan zone in Lyon, France, take part in a mock attack exercise as part of security preparations for the Euro 2016 football championship.
item.description: With 51 games in 10 cities over the next month, France’s security forces fear that the tournament could provide a number of targets for terrorist groups.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Eritrean Accused of Trafficking Migrants Is Captured in Sudan
item.media:description: European Union delegates paid tribute before rows of coffins at an airport hangar in Lampedusa, Italy, in 2013. The coffins held the bodies of the victims of the shipwreck that killed more than 300 migrants off the Sicilian island.
item.media:credit: Roberto Salomone/European Commission, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Extradited to Italy, Medhanie Yehdego Mered is suspected of helping lead a ring linked to the deaths of 359 people off Italy in 2013.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI and SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: U.N. Accuses Eritrea’s Leaders of Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Yemane Gebreab, an adviser to the president of Eritrea, arrived at a news conference in Geneva on Wednesday to respond to the report by the United Nations commission.
item.description: A commission urged the Security Council to refer human rights violations by “officials at the highest levels of state” to the International Criminal Court.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Drug That Killed Prince Is Making Mexican Cartels Richer, U.S. Says
item.media:description: Prince performing during halftime of the Super Bowl in Miami in 2007. The music icon, who struggled with debilitating pain, died from an accidental overdose of fentanyl in April.
item.description: American officials warn that the cartels are using their own labs to produce fentanyl, a synthetic opioid tied to a rise in overdose deaths.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Papua New Guinea Protesters Wounded by Police Gunfire, Lawmaker Says
item.description: Officials said some demonstrators had been wounded, but none killed. Students have been demanding that Prime Minister Peter O’Neill resign.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Sinosphere: Animal Advocates Call for End to Dog Meat Festival in China
item.media:description: Dogs on sale at a marketplace in Yulin during the city’s dog meat festival last year.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A petition was presented to the Chinese Embassy in London, and campaigners plan to bring a copy to officials in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG

item.title: Abu Sayyaf Militants in Philippines Release 4 Kidnapped Sailors
item.description: The four Malaysian crew members were abducted from their tugboat off Borneo island on April 1. It could not be confirmed if any ransom was paid.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Trilobites: Four Elements on the Periodic Table Get New Names
item.media:description: Kosuke Morita, center, led the researchers at the Riken institute in Japan, which discovered element 113. It now has the proposed name of Nihonium.
item.media:credit: The Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press Images
item.description: Names were proposed for four elements on the table’s seventh row: Nihonium, moscovium, tennessine and oganesson.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR
item.category: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry

item.title: Sinkhole Opens Under Busy Street in Downtown Ottawa
item.description: A shopping mall, offices, hotel and convention center were evacuated and a minivan was swallowed up, but there were no immediate reports of injuries.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Russian Court Frees Artist Known for Needling Putin Government
item.description: In a surprise ruling, Pyotr Pavlensky escaped with a fine after setting fire to the front door of Lubyanka, the headquarters of Russia’s main intelligence agency.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Arrieta Journal: Top Chefs and Local Farmers in Spain Regenerate Their ‘Green Caviar’
item.media:description: Iker Villasana Hernaez picking the highly prized “guisante lágrima,” or “tear pea,” at his farm in Arrieta, Spain. He feels each pod before deciding whether it is ready to pick.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: The “guisante lágrima,” or “tear pea,” a highly prized vegetable, exemplifies the symbiotic relationship between Spain’s leading chefs and local farmers.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Suzuki Chairman to Step Down as Chief Executive After Fuel Economy Scandal
item.media:description: Osamu Suzuki married into the Suzuki Motors founding family in the late 1950s, and became president of the carmaker in 1978.
item.description: The management shuffle is the latest in a wave of auto-industry overhauls resulting from improper tests.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Far-Right Party in Austria Challenges Results of Presidential Vote
item.description: The Freedom Party, whose candidate, Norbert Hofer, narrowly lost a May 22 runoff, said there were electoral irregularities.
item.dc:creator: KIMBERLY BRADLEY

item.title: Toxic Fish in Vietnam Idle a Local Industry and Challenge the State
item.media:description: Dead fish on a beach in the central province of Quang Binh, Vietnam. Pollution from a nearby steel plant is suspected in the die-off, and protests across the country are testing the government.
item.description: Hundreds have been sickened by tainted fish up and down the coast from a new steel plant, and escalating protests have grown into a test of government accountability.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Monkey in Kenya Survives After Setting Off Nationwide Blackout
item.media:description: A monkey that climbed onto the roof of the Gitaru Power Station in Kenya fell or jumped onto a transformer, causing a power outage. The monkey survived and was given to Kenya’s wildlife services.
item.description: The primate jumped on a transformer at a hydroelectric power station, starting a chain reaction that knocked out lights and the internet.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: U.S. Accuses Chinese Jet of Flying Too Close to American Plane
item.media:description: Adm. Harry B. Harris Jr., the head of the United States Pacific Command.
item.media:credit: Logan Mock-Bunting for The New York Times
item.description: The episode was the second report of an unsafe intercept recently by a Chinese jet tracking an American spy plane in the waters around China.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Question of Identity: Why Britain Is Edging Toward ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: A “Vote Leave” rally in Manchester, England. Betting markets still suggest that Britain will remain in the European Union, but recent polls have shown a lead for the “leave” camp.
item.description: Sometimes, one issue can have a big influence on an election. Immigration may turn out to be that issue on June 23.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS

item.title: What in the World: A Chinese Delicacy Straight From the Swiftlet’s Mouth
item.description: Bird’s nest soup, including bird saliva, is supposed to improve the immune system, skin and sex drive. The demand means trouble for the birds themselves.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: An All-Purpose Maze Deep Beneath a London Suburb
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photos by Jag_cz, Andrey Yurlov, Ollie, Graeme Dawes/shutterstock
item.description: The Chislehurst Caves have been an arsenal, a bomb shelter, a concert site, a film set, and once even a makeshift maternity ward. But they’ve never been caves.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: What in the World: In Croatia, You’ll Finally No Longer Need the Stamp of Approval
item.description: The centuries-old ritual of the rubber stamp and its “clah-thunk” for documents is giving way to digital in a country bogged down by bureaucracy.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH OROVIC

item.title: Op-Docs: Afghanistan by Choice
item.description: How do you make the wrenching decision of whether to leave your home?

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why French Workers Are So Mad
item.description: The government says more “flexibility” will create jobs, but the people of France know better.
item.dc:creator: SYLVAIN CYPEL

item.title: Editorial: China Should Shut Down Zombie Businesses to Help the Economy
item.media:description: Worker at a steel mill in Changzhou, China.
item.description: Unprofitable enterprises are being kept alive by the government’s reluctance to act.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
